questions.text: Which of the following is a non-enveloped DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus is a non-enveloped DNA virus. The DNA is double-stranded.

Adenovirus has a unique shape. The capsid has capsomeres arranged as an icosahedron, with rod-like projections having knobs at the tips. This gives adenovirus the appearance of a space vehicle.

They infect humans, animals, and birds, showing strict host specificity. Adenovirus infections are common worldwide, mostly in children. Many infections are asymptomatic. The virus may persist in the host for many months. They cause infections of the respiratory tract and eyes, and less often of the intestine and urinary tract.

Common syndromes associated with adenovirus infection: 
 
Syndrome Principal serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia  3, 4, 7, 14, 21 
Acute respiratory diseases in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis (in children)

 11, 21

questions.text:
A 37-week primigravid mother presents to you in active labor. Her serology done 2 weeks before revealed the following findings. What is the best step in the management of the newborn?
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
Anti-HBc IgG positive

HBIG- Hepatitis B immune globulin

choices.text: Single-dose HBIG and vaccination after 1 week

questions.solution:
The best step for an infant born to a hepatitis B carrier mother is single-dose HBIG and routine vaccination.

This pregnant woman having HBeAg and HBsAg positive with anti-HBc-IgG positive has a chronic hepatitis B viral (HBV) infection or is in a chronic carrier state. Both of the above scenarios put the infant at risk of HBV transmission. The recommended management is to give a single dose of hepatitis B immune globulin immediately and the first dose or routine vaccination within 12 hours of birth. HBIG confers passive immunity and is also given to persons exposed to HBV percutaneously or by contamination of mucosal surfaces along with the HBV vaccine. HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

Interferon alfa, entecavir, and tenofovir are first-line treatments indicated for patients with chronic active hepatitis to prevent the progression of liver fibrosis. It is not indicated as prophylaxis for babies born to seropositive mothers.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with bilateral cheek swelling,  pain, tenderness, and fever for the last two days. Which of the following is not a complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a parotid swelling with fever is suggestive of mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of this disease. SSPE is caused by a measles infection.

Mumps is an infection caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It causes non-suppurative inflammation and growth of the parotid glands. 

The mode of infection is inhalation or contact through the conjunctiva. The virus infects the respiratory tract leading to replication and dissemination through the cervical lymph nodes and bloodstream. The incubation period is about 12-25 days

Mumps infection usually presents with unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling. Unilateral disease usually progresses to bilateral involvement. It is accompanied by fever, local pain and tenderness but the skin over the gland is not warm or erythematous. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within a week. However, the involvement of other organs is detrimental and leads to severe complications.

Complications of mumps infection: 

  1. Epidymo-orchitis (Option A) is characterized by swollen, intensely painful testicles. This is usually associated with fever and chills. This may lead to testicular atrophy and decreased sperm counts. 
  2. Meningoencephalitis (Option B) or meningitis can occur. This is usually aseptic and is characterized by pleocytosis on cerebrospinal fluid examination. This may lead to deafness as a complication. 
  3. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) can occur. This generally resolves with conservative treatment. 
  4. Arthritis may occur with monoarticular or polyarticular involvement. 
  5. Myocardial involvement: Transient ECG changes are seen. Rapidly progressive myocarditis can occur.

A typical case of mumps needs no laboratory confirmation, but in atypical cases and complications, diagnosis may be established by virus isolation and serological tests.

Prophylaxis of mumps is done through the administration of an effective live virus vaccine containing the Jeryl-Lynn strain of the virus. The vaccine is given as a single subcutaneous injection, alone or in combination with the measles and rubella vaccines (Measles - Mumps - Rubella vaccine: MMR vaccine)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visited the local WHO camp with fever, headache, and joint pain for a month followed by trouble sleeping, and confusion. She gives a history of some insect bite, followed by the development of a painless chancre at the site. Examination revealed posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood examination shows the following findings. What is the vector for the likely disease?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of joint pain, trouble sleeping, and confusion in a patient with a history of insect bite and the development of a painless chancre at the bite site with examination findings revealing posterior cervical lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom’s sign) and hepatosplenomegaly and microscopy showing spindle-shaped organisms with an undulating membrane and flagellum is suggestive of African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei. The vector is the Tse-Tse fly.

Trypanosoma brucei

It is seen with an elongated body supporting a longitudinal lateral undulating membrane and a flagellum that borders the free edge of the membrane and emerges at the anterior end as a whiplike extension. The kinetoplast (circular DNA inside the single mitochondrion) is a darkly stained body lying next to the basal body from which the flagellum arises. T brucei, rhodesiense, and T brucei gambiense are indistinguishable morphologically.

The most reliable method for differentiating the trypomastigotes of T. brucei and T. cruzi is by the size of the kinetoplast. T. brucei has a relatively small kinetoplast, while T. cruzi has a larger kinetoplast.

Stages of African sleeping sickness:

Stage I – no CNS involvement

  • Painless chancre at the site of bite of Tsetse fly.
  • Initially, in the first stage of the disease, there are fevers, headaches, itchiness, and joint pains. This begins one to three weeks after the bite
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the posterior cervical region (Winterbottom’s sign)
  • Myocarditis
  • Hematological - anemia, moderate leucocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. High levels of immunoglobulins mainly immunoglobulin (IgM) are a constant feature.

Stage II – CNS invasion

  • Weeks to months later the second stage begins with confusion, poor coordination, numbness, and trouble sleeping.
  • Sleeping sickness, extrapyramidal symptoms, coma, and death

Other options:

Option B: Female Phlebotomus sandfly transmits Leishmaniasis. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Triatomine bug (Reduviid bug/ kissing bug) transmits Trypanosoma cruzi infection leading to Chaga's disease or American trypansomiasis. The acute phase of the disease is characterized by a typical subcutaneous lesion at the site of inoculation called chagoma. In the chronic phase, multiorgan involvement occurs leading to cardiac myopathy, megaesophagus, and megacolon.

Option D: Female anopheles mosquito leads to the transmission of malaria caused by Plasmodium species. Malaria can present with fever and hepatosplenomegaly but the morphological forms commonly include the ring forms or the gametocytes.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days ago. His blood investigations revealed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy findings are given in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy findings showing encysted spiral larvae are characteristic of Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

questions.text: A sanitation worker presents with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia. He develops pigmentation on the tip of the nose in a few days. The serum NS1 antigen test is negative. Which of the following is correct about the likely disease?

choices.text: The causative organism is a Flavivirus
Patients usually end up with hypovolemic shock
It is described as a biphasic illness
It is frequently associated with thrombocytopenia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sanitation worker presenting with fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia and pigmentation on the tip of the nose (chik sign) is suggestive of a Chikungunya virus infection. It is described as a biphasic illness with an acute phase characterized by polyarthralgia, high fever, headache, vomiting, rash, and myalgia, and a chronic phase (chronic rheumatologic condition) characterized by chronic arthritis.

Chikungunya is a viral disease that belongs to the Togaviridae family. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors. Patients present with saddle-back fever, conjunctival suffusion, and photophobia. Migratory arthralgia, especially involving small joints, may also be seen. A maculopapular or petechial rash is frequently seen on the trunk which may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Clinically, chikungunya cannot be differentiated from uncomplicated dengue; however, it usually is not followed by hemorrhagic fever. Thrombocytopenia and hypovolemic shock are complications seen with dengue (flavivirus) and are unlikely in Chikungunya.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling greenish discharge from the vagina. She also mentions vaginal itching and irritation. Which of the following is true regarding the likely causative organism?

choices.text: It is non-motile on wet mount
It cannot exist outside the human body
It does not affect male patients

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It cannot exist outside the human body, as it exists only as a trophozoite without any cyst stage. 

It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with vaginal, urethral, or prostatic tissues. Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. 

The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul-smelling, frothy vaginal discharge, itching, dysuria, and dyspareunia. Punctate and petechial hemorrhages and mucosal capillary dilation give the appearance of a strawberry cervix. Chicken-like epithelium occurs due to intracellular edema which is also a characteristic feature.

The image below shows the strawberry cervix seen in trichomoniasis:

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of mobility on the wet saline mount (option A). The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium or plastic envelope medium (PEM) (option C). The treatment of choice is metronidazole 2 g orally as a single dose.

In men, trichomoniasis has also been associated with infertility through inflammatory damage to the genitourinary tract, so the treatment of both partners is necessary (option D).

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the thin blood smear showing the maltese cross appearance (black arrow) and ring form (yellow arrow) is suggestive of Babesia microti infection.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts.

Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum.

Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment:

Mild: Atovaquone + Azithromycin
Severe: Clindamycin + quinine
Fulminant case: exchange transfusion

questions.text: The smallest unit of antigenicity is called
questions.solution:
The smallest unit of antigenicity is called the epitope or antigenic determinant. An epitope is defined as a small area present on the antigen that is capable of sensitizing immunocytes and reacting with a specific site of a T-cell receptor or an antibody.

A paratope (option B)is the specific site of an antibody that reacts with the corresponding epitope of an antigen.

Haptens are low molecular weight molecules that lack immunogenicity (cannot induce an immune response) themselves. They can become immunogenic by combining with a large molecule carrier. Haptens are classified as:

  • Complex haptens (option D): They contain two or more epitopes and can precipitate with specific antibodies.
  • Simple haptens (option C): They contain only one epitope. They bind to antibodies but are not precipitating.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis.  A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following antibodies is responsible for causing the initial negative result?
questions.solution:
The initial negative result while performing the standard agglutination test is due to the presence of blocking antibodies, mainly IgA antibodies. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test used to diagnose acute brucellosis. It mainly identifies IgM antibodies.

In this test, the IgA antibodies interfere with IgG and IgM agglutination, causing serologic test results to be negative in low serum dilutions but positive in higher dilutions. These antibodies appear during the subacute stage of infection, persist for many years regardless of the infection activity, and are identified using the Coombs antiglobulin method.

This is explained by the prozone phenomenon according to the lattice hypothesis. It refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to the inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in antigen-antibody interactions, eventually giving rise to a positive result. 

Brucellosis/ Undulant fever:

Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease caused by gram-negative, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B.melitensis, B. suis, and B.abortus. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products.

These bacteria proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system, which accounts for its resistance to simple antimicrobial therapy. 

Patients with acute infection may present with undulant fever, arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis includes:

  • Polymerase chain reaction 
  • Blood culture with Castaneda method
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test, Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 
  • Tests for animals and animal products: Milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.
    • Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed with stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies, agglutination occurs seen as a blue ring. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with IM streptomycin and oral doxycycline. Prevention of brucellosis can be achieved by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

The images below show the Casteneda's medium and the milk ring test respectively.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: You work in the Infection Control Committee of the hospital and are assigned the task of inspecting the disinfection and sterilization protocols of the operating room. What procedure should be followed to sterilize the urethroscope used?
questions.solution:
The sterilization of scopes such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes is done by plasma sterilization.

Plasma contains ions, electrons, and neutral particles. This state is produced by the application of radio frequency energy to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapors are passed. This generates plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen which are used to sterilize articles such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes.

Other options :

Gamma radiation and ethylene oxide gas sterilization is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

Autoclaving is used to sterilize surgical linens, culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of change in color of the toenails for the past 3 months. Examination reveals onycholysis. He did not give any history of trauma. The Lactophenol Cotton Blue mount done from the nail sample reveals the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following can be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophytic fungus which is the most common pathogen in onychomycosis. 

The given history is suggestive of onychomycosis and lactophenol cotton blue (LCB) mount from the nail sample shows the presence of slender septate hyphae with a few pencil-shaped macroconidia is characteristic of T. rubrum.

Trichophyton species can infect skin, hair, and nails.

Other options:

Option A: Microsporum shows abundant, thick-walled, spindle-shaped macroconidia with septa. Microsporum species infect the hair and skin but usually not the nails.

Option B: Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra.

Option D: Epidermophyton shows club-shaped macroconidia in clusters. Microconidia are absent. It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought with forgetfulness, behavioral changes, and visual hallucinations for the past 4 months. He is not able to button his shirt and tie his shoelaces for the last 1 month. Diagnosis of a subacute spongiform encephalopathy is made. This is caused by:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of memory loss with incoordination is suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a type of subacute spongiform encephalopathy, which is caused by prions.

Prions are proteinaceous infective particles that are transmissible. They are virus-like agents devoid of nucleic acid. They are small particles, resistant to heat, UV rays, and nucleases, and sensitive to proteases.

The pathogenic mechanism is the proliferation of an abnormal prion protein (PrPsc) which is derived from the normal cellular prion protein (PrPc). The accumulation of PrPsc in the CNS as diffuse deposits and in the form of plaques disrupts the architecture and function of the brain.

They are slow viral diseases that produce chronic progressive degenerative diseases of the CNS. They are collectively called subacute spongiform encephalopathies and includes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, kuru and Gerstmann-Sträussler syndrome. Most of these diseases are rapidly progressive and even fatal.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a human prion disease. It is subacute, presenile encephalopathy, with progressive incoordination and dementia, ending fatally in about a year. Both sporadic and inherited forms of the disease have been seen. Iatrogenic CJD has occurred after corneal transplantation and injection of the pituitary growth hormone, presumably from donors who had the infection.

Other options:

Option A: Lentivirus belongs to a group A slow viruses. It causes a slowly progressive infection in sheep. 

Option B: Cryptosporidium parvum causes chronic profuse diarrhea in immunocompromised patients, which can lead to water and electrolyte depletion and weight loss.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia usually causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients.

Related Pearl: Slow Virus Diseases

Slow virus diseases are characterized by a long asymptomatic period, often months or years in duration, between the introduction of the infectious agent and the appearance of clinical illness.

It can be classified into 3 groups:

Group A: Slowly progressive infections of sheep

  • Visna
  • Medi

Group B: Prion diseases

Prion Diseases of Animals

  • Scrapie
  • MINK encephalopathy
  • Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

Prion Diseases of Humans

  • CJD
  • Kuru
  • Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinkersyndrome
  • Fatal familial insomnia

Group C

  • SSPE
  • PML

questions.text: A 34-year-old male who was newly diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated prior to initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following techniques is used to determine the CD4+ cell count in his peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is used to determine the CD4 count in the peripheral blood.

Flow cytometry is a laser based method which analyzes the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Flow cytometry is routinely used in identifying CD4-positive cells, CD8-positive cells, B cells, macrophages, and cells expressing a variety of cytokines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with features mimicking appendicitis. Upon removal, the appendix is found to be grossly and histologically normal. A stool examination revealed motile gram-negative rods with a safety pin appearance. What is the etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
It is a case of pseudo-appendicitis (appendicitis-like syndrome), caused by Yersinia enterocolitica. The picture showing bipolar staining or safety pin appearance is suggestive of Yersinia species on Wayson stain.

Yersinia enterocolitica is a gram-negative bacillus with a safety pin appearance. It causes gastroenteritis or mesenteric lymphadenitis after ingestion of contaminated food or water. 

In young children, it causes a self-limiting diarrheal illness. Patients with HLA-B27 who were infected with Y. enterocolitica develop arthralgia, arthritis, and erythema nodosum. 

Yersinia can be recovered from the stool of infected patients using selective media called CIN (Cefsulodin-Irgasan-Novobiocin) agar incubated at room temperature. Their colonies have a bull's eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Yersinia enterocolitica is motile at 25 °C, which differentiates it from Y. pestis which is non-motile.

Treatment for gastroenteritis caused by Y. enterocolitica consists of ciprofloxacin or a third-generation cephalosporin.

Other options : 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is a long slender gram-positive bacillus. It has large spores which are oval and subterminal. It is an opportunistic organism that rarely causes disease and does so only when normal flora is lost. It causes acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi are gram-negative rods that are motile with peritrichous flagella. It causes enteric fever or typhoid fever. 

Option C: Vibrio parahaemolyticus resembles V. cholera in its morphology except that it is capsulated shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. Strains isolated from humans are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar (special high salt blood agar). This is known as the Kanagawa phenomenon. It causes food poisoning associated with marine food intake. Abdominal pain, vomiting diarrhea, and fever are the usual signs.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and constipation. Upon examination, the physician notes a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: This condition is caused by an exotoxin
The toxin type G is associated with sudden death
Detection of antitoxin can aid in diagnosis
The toxin causes spastic paralysis by blocking the release of Acetylcholine

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of infant botulism. Statement 4 is the false statement since the toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine.

Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, and is of three types:

  • Foodborne botulism
  • Infant botulism
  • Wound botulism

Infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome): It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months; It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxin. The characteristic clinical history is paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weak, altered cry, and loss of head control. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxin or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

Other options:

  • Clostridium botulinum produces a powerful exotoxin that is responsible for its pathogenicity.
  • The toxin type G is associated with sudden death.
  • A retrospective diagnosis can be made by detection of antitoxin in the serum but it may not be seen in all cases.

Gram staining of clostridium botulinum:

questions.text: A senior resident uses Diene’s stain to stain the micro-organisms which appear as shown below. This characteristic appearance is shown by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Diene's method of staining is used for diagnosis of mycoplasma. It is also known as Eaton agent since Eaton was the first person to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. 

The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance, consisting of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent peripheral zone. 

Mycoplasma colonies can be studies either with a hand or after staining with Diene's method. For Diene's method, a block of agar containing the colony is cut and placed on a slide. It is covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried. 

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are higly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections.

 

Related Pearl: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria:

Common name Scientific name
Klebs-Loffler bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheria

Hansen’s bacillus Mycobacterium leprae

Pfeiffer’s bacillus Haemophilus influenza
Friedlander’s bacillus Klebsiella pneumoniae

questions.text: Satellitism in H. influenza demonstrates the dependence of:
questions.solution:
Satellitism in H.influenza demonstrates the dependence of Factor V.

This phenomenon is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller, farther away from the streak.

This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus and factor V is required for the growth of H. influenza.

Factor V is a co-enzyme, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), or NAD phosphate (NADP) which acts as a hydrogen acceptor in the metabolism of the cell. It is heat-labile, being destroyed at 120°C in a few minutes. It is present in red blood cells and in many other animal and plant cells.

Factor X is hemin or other porphyrins required for the synthesis of cytochrome and other heme enzymes such as catalase and peroxidase involved in aerobic respiration. It is heat stable.

questions.text: A  26-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis with the classical "kissing ulcer" appearance. He also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.  Which of the following will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender genital ulcers with the "kissing ulcer" appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy most likely has a diagnosis of chancroid. The classical "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance will be found on microscopy of the smear from these lesions, as shown below:

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings, "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance.

Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform and treat their sexual partners from the last 3 months.

Other options:

(B) Spirochetes are seen on dark field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis can be confirmed by specific treponemal tests such as fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS), Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test (TPHA), and the enzyme immunoassay (EIA). Treatment is with parental penicillin G, irrespective of the stage of the disease. Dose and duration depend on the clinical stage and presentation. In the case of penicillin hypersensitivity, regimens based on doxycycline, erythromycin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol are used for treatment.

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes are shown below:


(C) Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Management is with a course of azithromycin.

The slide below shows Donovan bodies with the safety-pin appearance:


(D) Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base with painful inguinal lymph nodes. The diagnosis can be made with an initial Tzanck smear by deroofing the vesicles and taking a swab. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to confirm this diagnosis. The first-line drug used to treat herpes genitalis is oral aciclovir.

Tzanck smear with the above-mentioned findings can be seen below:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: An outbreak of hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) occurs in a village. The implicated virus is found to belong to the Bunyaviridae family. What category of bioterrorism agent would this virus belong to?
questions.solution:
The causative agent for the outbreak of hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) belonging to the Bunyaviridae family is Hantavirus. Hantavirus is classified as a category C bioterrorism agent. 

Bioterrorism refers to the intentional release of a harmful agent by attackers to cause diseases or fatalities within the human population or impact food crops and livestock. The aim is to instill fear among civilians or influence governmental actions.

As per the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the agents associated with bioterrorism are categorized into three distinct classes, namely Category A, Category B, and Category C. There is no designated Category D within this classification.

Category C bioterrorism agents encompass emerging pathogens, such as Nipah and Hantavirus. These agents possess characteristics that make them susceptible to potential engineering for widespread dissemination in the future. Factors contributing to this risk include their ready availability, elevated mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of both production and dissemination.

Hantaviruses, classified under Bunyaviridae, are rodent-borne viruses primarily transmitted through inhalation of the virus present in the dried excreta of rodents. It causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) or hantavirus pulmonary syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding bacterial cell wall morphology.

choices.text: Gram-negative cell walls have teichoic acid
Gram-positive cell walls have a pentaglycine bridge
Gram-negative cell walls have a thick peptidoglycan layer

questions.solution:
The gram-positive cell walls have a pentaglycine bridge in their peptidoglycan layer. Hence, option C is the correct statement.

The cell wall serves as a tough and rigid outer layer of a bacterial cell. Gram-positive and gram-negative cell walls are different in their structure in the following ways:

  Gram-positive Gram-negative
Peptidoglycan layer

Thick (50-100 layers)

 Thin (1-2 layers)
Pentaglycine bridge in the peptidoglycan layer Present Absent
Lipopolysaccharide Absent Present (serves as endotoxin)
Teichoic acid Present Absent
Aromatic amino acids Absent Present

questions.text: Which of the following inclusion bodies are intranuclear in location?
questions.solution:
Lipschultz bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies (Cowdry type A) produced by Herpes simplex viruses.

Intranuclear inclusion bodies are basophilic in nature. They are classified into Cowdry type A and Cowdry type B.

Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies are cytopathologic changes produced by Herpes simplex viruses seen on a Tzanck smear. Cowdry type A bodies are variable in size and have a granular appearance. Other histopathologic changes produced by HSV on Tzank smear include multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells), and ballooning of infected cells.

Cowdry type B intranuclear inclusion bodies are more circumscribed and usually multiple. They are caused by Adenovirus and Poliovirus. Other causes of intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies are described in the pearl below.

Other options: 

Option B: Molluscum bodies or Henderson–Patterson bodies are large, eosinophilic, hyaline, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies caused by Molluscum contagiosum. These bodies are composed of a large number of virus particles embedded in a protein matrix.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are seen inside large, mononuclear cells (pund cells) as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. They can have a characteristic safety pin appearance due to bipolar staining of the chromatin material.

 

Option D: Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies. They are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in sites usually devoid of inflammation. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with an erythematous rash on both cheeks for 2 days as shown below. He also had symptoms of fever, runny nose, and mild cough for 2 to 3 days. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image of slapped cheek appearance are strongly suggestive of Erythema Infectiosum/ Fifth disease. It is caused by Parvovirus B19.

Erythema infectiosum, a self-limiting disease, has three phases.

It begins abruptly with an asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks, referred to as “slapped cheek.” The erythema is typically diffuse and macular, but tiny translucent papules may be present.

After 1–4 days, the second phase begins, consisting of discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk. This evolves into a reticulate or lacy pattern.

A characteristic third phase is the recurring stage. The eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat when bathing) or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

About 7% of children with erythema infectiosum have arthralgias, whereas 80% of adults, especially women, have joint involvement.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of fever and a pruritic rash over her body after swimming at a resort 3 days ago. Lesion culture reveals oxidase-positive, gram-negative bacillus. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and a pruritic rash after swimming at a resort, with lesion culture revealing an oxidase-positive, gram-negative bacillus is suggestive of hot tub folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Hot tub folliculitis presents as itchy maculopapular vesicles or pustules, typically appearing 1-4 days after bathing in contaminated hot tubs and pools. Associated symptoms may include fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. Lesions are observed on the trunk, axillae, breasts, buttocks, and proximal extremities.

The image below shows hot tub folliculitis:

 

P. aeruginosa is an obligate aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, and oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. It produces a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. 

Diagnosis is helped by the fact that Pseudomonas grows well on most media with pigment production making its identification easy. It grows well on ordinary media, forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium, and is hemolytic on blood agar.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green-colored colonies is shown in the image below:

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva and around the anal region, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image showing multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal is characteristic of condyloma acuminata, also known as venereal warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV strains 6 and 11) is the organism responsible for this condition.

Condyloma acuminata presents as verrucous growths that may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They are mainly sexually transmitted and seen in women of childbearing age. In 20% of the cases, condyloma is associated with vulval, vaginal, and cervical cancers.

A colposcopic study of these lesions with 1% toluidine blue washed off with 3% acetic acid, one minute after the application is used to diagnose the vulval lesions. The normal skin allows the dye to be washed off, while the abnormal skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. Abnormal areas that are stained are biopsied. Histopathology will show koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. 

Treatment includes local application of 25% podophyllin or 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil repeated weekly. This treatment is, however, contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy and in vaginal and cervical lesions. Surgical excision of localized growth is another alternative option.

The pearl enlists the various types of genital lesions and their causative organisms.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is capable of undergoing genetic reassortment?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus containing segmented RNA genome is capable of undergoing genetic reassortment.

Virus reassortment is a process of genetic recombination exclusive to segmented RNA viruses which allows numerous viruses to co-infect a host cell and reassort gene segments, producing progeny viruses with unique genome combinations.

The most well-known example of reassortment in the context of interspecies transmission and the formation of pandemic viral strains (e.g. H1N1 strain in 2009) is seen in influenza viruses. 

The virus families containing segmented genome are : 

  • Orthomyxoviridae - 7 or 8 linear segments of single-stranded RNA( eg. Influenza virus)
  • Arenaviridae - 2 circular segments of single-stranded RNA( eg. Lassa fever virus, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus)
  • Bunyaviridae - 3 circular segments of single-stranded RNA(Hantavirus, California encephalitis virus)
  • Reoviridae - 10-12 segments of double-stranded RNA (Rotavirus, Colorado tick fever virus)

Other options:

Herpesvirus, Ebola virus and Poliovirus contain non-segmented genomes and therefore are not capable of undergoing genetic reassortment.

questions.text: An unconscious patient is brought to the emergency room. You plan to intubate the patient using the instrument shown in the image below. What is the criticality of the instrument according to the Spaulding classification and what level of disinfection is needed for this instrument?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image above is a Macintosh blade. It is a semicritical instrument according to the Spaulding classification and requires a high level of disinfection.

Semi-critical items are those that come in contact with mucous membranes or minor skin breaches (non-intact skin) and they need a high level of disinfection.

Spaulding classification is used to classify the devices used on the patient, which determines the type of method selected for disinfection or sterilization. The three categories of the devices are critical, semi-critical, or noncritical

The system also established three levels of germicidal activity for disinfection (high, intermediate, and low).

Spaulding Classification:

Body Contact Disinfection requirements FDA device Class
Intact skin Low level Non-critical

Mucous membranes/ non
intact skin

 High level Semi-critical
Sterile body cavity Sterilization Critical

 

Related Pearl: The Spaulding Classification

The Spaulding classification classifies medical devices according to the degree of risk of infection if they are contaminated.

Device

Description

Examples

Disinfection

Non-critical device

Lower risk of infection as the device comes in contact with intact or normal skin.

Stethoscope, walls, furniture, BP cuff, etc.

Intermediate/low-level disinfectant.

Clean, dry and store for future use.

Semi-critical devices

Lower risk of infection as these devices come in contact with mucosa and do not penetrate into sterile areas of the body.

Fiber-optic endoscopes, laryngoscopes, bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, vaginal specula, etc.

High-level disinfectant to be used after proper cleaning or sterilization by heat.

Critical devices

High risks of infection as these devices come in contact with sterile areas of the body like blood.

Needles, cardiac catheters, implants, intrauterine devices, urinary catheters, etc.

High-level disinfectant is indicated with sterilization with heat, ethylene oxide, etc.

questions.text: A 32-year-old-man, returning from Taiwan complains of fever and joint pain. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Tests reveal eosinophilia and stool microscopy is revealing of the given finding. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a round, non-operculated egg with a small lateral vestigial knob (as shown below by the red arrow) is suggestive of Katayama fever caused by Schistosoma japonicum.


S. japonicum, also known as Oriental blood fluke is prevalent in Southeast Asian countries. Man is the definitive host, but domestic animals and rodents can act as reservoirs of infection in endemic areas. Snails are the intermediate host. Freshwater cercaria is the infective form, which penetrates the skin and travels through venules into the systemic circulation. Following maturation in the intrahepatic portal veins, eggs are deposited in the superior mesenteric vein, which penetrates the gut wall and is passed into the feces.


The adult worms of S. japonicum are commonly seen in the superior mesenteric vein and its branches but also inhabit the inferior mesenteric vein, intrahepatic portal venules, and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.

After 4-8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia. Katayama fever caused by S. japonicum is more severe than in S. mansoni due to higher egg production.

Chronic infection is characterized by intestinal mucosal hyperplasia, portal hypertension, and clay pipestem fibrosis (hard liver and periportal fibrosis).

Other options: 

Option A and D: Eggs of S. hematobium and S. intercalatum are elongated and have terminal spines.

Option B: S. mansoni eggs are elongated and have a lateral spine.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: An adult male patient complaining of sore throat is suspected to have streptococcal pharyngitis based on Centor criteria. All of the following are components of Centor criteria, except:
questions.solution:
The presence of rhinorrhea is not a component of the Centor criteria. 

In patients with suspected streptococcal pharyngitis, the Centor criteria helps in determining management. It consists of four findings which is assigned 1 point each, and includes (1) history of fever, (2) absence of cough, (3) tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy and (4) tonsillar exudate or swelling. 

Sore throats are often caused by viruses and don't require antibiotics. However, Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is the only common bacterial cause of sore throat that needs antibiotic treatment. To identify patients with GAS pharyngitis, a scoring system is used to assess signs and symptoms and determine necessity of antibiotics. This helps avoid unnecessary antibiotic use for viral pharyngitis.

The Centor criteria helps assess and accurately stratify adult patients with suspected streptococcal pharyngitis. One point is allotted for each criterion, and the maximum score is 4.

For adults with suspected strep throat, no or only one Centor criteria indicates low probability of GAS pharyngitis and hence no testing or antibiotics are needed. If two or three Centor criteria are present (intermediate probablity), rapid antigen test is recommended to guide antibiotic treatment. If all four Centor criteria are present, either rapid testing or empiric antibiotics are indicated.

In children, the Centor criteria are less specific, and streptococcal pharyngitis should be confirmed with testing.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient presents with a sore throat, myalgias, fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. She is sexually active. Her peripheral smear is shown below. What will you advise this patient regarding her disease?

choices.text: Daily platelet counts till resolution of symptoms
Ask her to bring her partner for treatment
Avoid contact sports for a few weeks

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a teenager who is sexually active and a peripheral smear showing atypical lymphocytes indicates a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis/glandular fever. Upto 50% of patients with infectious mononucleosis usually develop splenomegaly and are advised to avoid contact sports for 6-8 weeks to prevent injury to the spleen. 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), also called Human Herpesvirus Type 4, is the causative organism for infectious mononucleosis, which is a lymphoproliferative disease transmitted by direct contact, commonly by saliva. 

The virus infects nasopharyngeal epithelial cells, salivary and lymphoid tissues by binding to the CD21 receptors. Latent infection of B cells, induces B-cell mitogenesis and results in the production of atypical reactive EBV specific CD8+ T cells (Downey cells). The B-cells produce antibodies that are reative to horse and sheep erythrocytes, called Heterophile antibodies, which are detected by the Paul-Bunnell or monospot test, which is one of the diagnostic tests for the disease.

Patients present with sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy and often splenomegaly associated with significant lymphocytosis. The diagnosis is usually based on the presence of atypical lymphocytes, a positive Paul-Bunnell test and positive titres of viral capsid antigen or EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) on ELISA. Early infection induces IgM formation, and later specific IgG which exists for life.

The disease is usually self-limiting and treatment is supportive in nature as in other viral infectious diseases. (Option B and D)

Other conditions caused by EBV infection include:

  • Hairy oral leukoplakia
  • Burkitt lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: The mecA gene is responsible for the resistance of which type of organism against which type of antimicrobial?
questions.solution:
The mecA gene is responsible for the resistance of S. aureus, a gram-positive cocci, against methicillin, which is a beta-lactam antibiotic.

Beta-lactam antibiotics act by binding to transpeptidases/penicillin-binding proteins and inhibit cell wall synthesis by the organism. Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene, which alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell wall to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

mecA gene is part of a larger chromosomal mobile genetic element called SCCmec. There are 12 different SCCmec types. Types I, II, III, VI, and VIII are associated with hospital-acquired methicillin-resistant S. aureus (HA- MRSA) infections. SCCmec type IV has been found mainly in community-acquired MRSA strains that tend to be less resistant and more transmissible.

Other options:

Option B: An example of resistance of gram-positive cocci against aminoglycosides is the resistance of S. aureus against Vancomycin, due to the acquisition of van-A genes which is transposon-mediated. 

Options C and D: Gram-negative bacteria have resistance against macrolides and fluoroquinolones by various mechanisms such as reduced permeability, efflux pumps, and target modification, none of which are mediated by the mecA gene.

 

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

  2. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  3. Multiple sclerosis
  4. Atopic dermatitis
  5. Psoriasis
  6. Serum sickness
questions.solution:
The examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity:

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Psoriasis

Other options:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia - Type II
  • Atopic dermatitis - Type I
  • Serum sickness - Type III

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents to the OPD with the following lesions. On microscopy from tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region, and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. Itraconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver - cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other treatment options for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:

  • Terbinafine
  • SSKI- Saturated solution of potassium iodide
  • Fluconazole
  • Local hyperthermia

Pulmonary sporotrichosis & osteoarticular sporotrichosis are also treated with itraconazole in mild to moderate cases. But, liposomal amphotericin B can be used in patients that are seriously ill with severe or life-threatening disease.

Meningeal sporotrichosis is treated with amphotericin B, as it is the drug of choice for meningeal sporotrichosis. Itraconazole is used for step-down therapy in these patients. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
Match the culture medium with the organism it is used for-
Culture media Organism
1. Wilson and Blair A. Legionella pneumophila
2. Sorbitol MacConkey B. Salmonella typhi
3. BCYE agar  C. Corynebacterium diphtheriae
4. Skirrow’s medium D. Escherichia coli O157:H7
5. Macleod’s medium E. Campylobacter jejuni
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correct one is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-E, 5-C.

1. Wilson and Blair B. Salmonella typhi
2. Sorbitol MacConkey D. Escherichia coli O157:H7
3. BCYE agar  A. Legionella pneumophila
4. Skirrow’s medium E. Campylobacter jejuni
5. Macleod’s medium C. Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

An image of Wilson and Blair's medium is given below-

Sorbitol MacConkey is used for identifying E. coli O157:H7. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC) O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. 

An image of the Sorbitol MacConkey medium is given below- 

BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species which are nutritionally fastidious.

Composition of BCYE Agar-

  • Agar
  • ACES buffer- To maintain the pH for optimal growth
  • Yeast extract- Supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  • Charcoal- Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species.
  • L-Cysteine- It is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  • Ferric Pyrophosphate- Used as an iron source
  • Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt- Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth.

An image of BCYE agar is given below-

Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

An image of Skirrow's medium is given below- 

Macleod medium is selective for Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Potassium tellurite in McLeod's medium or Potassium Tellurite Agar is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

An image of McLeod medium is given below-

questions.text: Which of the following is a dimorphic fungi?
questions.solution:
Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungi.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi are:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillosis marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum

Option A: Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Option C: Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is a yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudohyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue. They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.

Option D: Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic pathogen that causes aspergillosis. It is a non-dimorphic mould with septate hyphae that branch at a V-shaped angle. It forms characteristic mycelium when cultured on Sabouraud’s agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

  • Molds
