  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a painless swelling over his left foot with multiple sinuses discharging pus and black granules. Pus from the sinuses was sent for investigations and the microscopic appearance of the causative agent is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario as well as the above image showing darkly stained fungal hyphae on microscopy suggests a likely diagnosis of eumycetoma.

Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as maduramycosis or madura foot. It is caused by various types of fungi (eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes). 

Eumycetoma is caused by fungi like Madurella mycetomatis. It usually enters the body through minor trauma. The disease usually begins as a small subcutaneous swelling of the foot. It enlarges and burrows into the deeper tissues and tracks to the surface as multiple sinuses discharging seropurulent fluid containing hard, black granules. 

Examination and culture of the granules and biopsy of the lesion help in ascertaining the diagnosis. Diagnosis is confirmed by isolating Madurella mycetomatis on culture on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA).

The image below shows a eumycetoma of the foot:

Eumycetoma is treated by surgical debridement of the lesion and administering antifungals for 18-24 months(even in the absence of clinical or laboratory evidence of infection).

Other options:

Option A: Botryomycosis is a mycetoma-like lesion caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: Sporotrichosis is a localized skin and subcutaneous tissue infection caused by Sporothrix schenkii. A papule is seen at the site of inoculation followed by the development of similar lesions along the lymphatic channels. Histopathology shows a mixed granulomatous and pyogenic reaction, and tiny oval or cigar-shaped yeasts.

The image below shows a picture of Actinomycetes on Gram staining:

Option D: Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It commonly presents as warty, cutaneous nodules resembling the florets of cauliflower. Histologically, the lesions contain the fungus, which is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, known as sclerotic bodies. The image below shows sclerotic bodies, seen on histopathology examination.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the casualty by his friends after the consumption of the recreational drug- magic mushrooms. On examination, he is delirious and has visual and auditory hallucinations. Blood and urine samples are sent for toxicological analysis which shows the presence of d-lysergic acid. Which among the following did the boy consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing hallucinations and the presence of d-lysergic acid is suggestive of the consumption of Psilocybe species of mushrooms/fungi which exhibits mycetism.

Mycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and Mycotoxicosis

Mycetism:

The fungus when eaten, itself causes toxic effects. The hallucinogenic agents (d-lysergic acid and psilocybin) produced by Psilocybe species have attracted attention as recreational drugs in recent years. 

Other fungi which that show mycotic poisoning in the form of mycetism include:

  • Claviceps → Ergot poisoning
  • Coprine → coprine poisoning
  • Inocybe → muscarine poisoning

Mycotoxicosis:

Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus (secretes B1) and A. parasiticus (secretes B1, B2, G1 and G2)
  • Fusarium toxins

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases are likely to be associated with the antigen (marked by black arrow) shown in the image below?
  1. Toxic shock syndrome
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. B cell lymphoma
  4. Rheumatic fever
  5. Amoebiasis
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a superantigen. The diseases associated with superantigens are 

  1. Toxic shock syndrome
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. B cell lymphoma
  4. Rheumatic fever

Amoebiasis is caused by the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. Superantigens are usually viral or bacterial proteins. Hence, amoebiasis is not likely to be associated with superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of a T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity, i.e., they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

They are viral or bacterial protein toxins that activate the immune system by binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules and T-cell receptors (TCR) and stimulate large numbers of T cells to produce massive quantities of cytokines, in particular, IFN-γ.

 IFN-γ in turn activates macrophages to produce IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, all of which may contribute to a “cytokine storm” causing severe symptoms of shock and multiple organ failure.

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.
  • They are highly resistant to proteases and to denaturation by CD4+ T cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocapsid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.

Diseases associated with Superantigens:

  • Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS)
  • Streptococcal TSS
  • Food poisoning
  • Rheumatic fever
  • B cell lymphoma 
  • HIV and AIDS
  • Rabies
  • Tuberculosis
  • Psoriasis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever, urticaria, wheezing and colicky abdominal pain. Stool examination revealed the following egg. Identify the false statement regarding this nematode.

choices.text: Egg containing filariform larva is infective

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the egg shown in the image are suggestive of ascariasis caused by Ascaris lumbricoides. An embryonated egg containing the rhabditiform larva is the infective form.

The image given shows an elliptical-shaped egg with a thin irregular shell containing a mass of disorganized granules, suggestive of an unfertilized Ascaris egg.

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host. The infection is acquired via the consumption of food or water contaminated with eggs. The eggs hatch after reaching the duodenum to release rhabditiform larvae. These penetrate the intestinal mucosa and enter the portal vessels. From the liver, larvae reach the systemic circulation, and lungs and then reach the small intestine to produce symptoms.

The life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides is given below.

 

Clinical features due to the migrating larvae are fever, dry cough, and asthmatic wheezing. Loeffler's syndrome may be present which is characterized by the presence of larvae in the sputum or gastric washing. Chest imaging may show signs of eosinophilic pneumonitis.

Individuals infected by the adult worm can be asymptomatic but can also present with protein-energy malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, toxic effects like urticaria, and angioedema due to hypersensitivity.

The worms can clump together and give rise to a volvulus, intussusception, intestinal obstruction, or even perforation. Additionally, they can also cause ectopic ascariasis, resulting in acute biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, and obstructive appendicitis.

Treatment includes pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, mebendazole, or ivermectin. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps with the isolated bacteria fermenting lactose and forming colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar is suggestive of infection by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) O157: H7, also known as Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC).

O157: H7 is the most common type of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Unlike most other E. coli serotypes, the STEC O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. All species of E. coli are lactose fermenters and produce pink colonies.

They produce two antigenic forms of the cytotoxic toxin known as Shiga-like toxin 1 and Shiga-like toxin 2. Shiga-like toxin 1 is identical to the Shiga toxin of Shigella dysenteriae type 1. E. coli O157:H7 has a small infective dose (around 100 bacilli) and spreads easily from child to child by the feco-oral route.

It can cause mild non-bloody diarrhea to hemorrhagic colitis, or a severe form of diarrhea, with hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease resulting in acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in the world is E.coli O157:H7. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in India is Shigella dysenteriae type I.

Other options:

Option A: Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. They grow at a slower rate and thus require selective media containing antibiotics like Skirrow's media for culture.

Option B: Yersinia enterocolitica causes diarrhea with symptoms resembling appendicitis (pseudoappendicitis). The patients present with abdominal pain which can be localized to the right iliac fossa, thus mimicking appendicitis. Additionally, it is a non-lactose fermenter.

Option D: Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce the Shiga toxin and result in a clinical profile similar to EHEC. But Shigella is a non-lactose fermenting organism, unlike E. coli, and will form pale colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

Non-lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below?

choices.text: It exists as a monomer in serum.
It is the second most abundant class of serum immunoglobulins.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, which is characteristic of secretory IgA; the incorrect statement is that it is a heat-labile antibody. 

IgE is the only heat-labile antibody; this is a property unique to IgE. It is inactivated when heated at 56°C for one hour.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, as well as in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

IgA is the second most abundant class of antibodies, comprising about 10–13% of the serum immunoglobulins. The most abundant serum immunoglobulin is IgG. The order of abundance of the different immunoglobulins in serum is given as IgG > IgA > IgM > IgD > IgE.

When present in the serum, IgA exists as a monomer, similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule
  • The secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A patient presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for 3 days. His stools were greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample showed the presence of trophozoites shaped liked a tennis racket. What is the likely causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child having loose greasy, foul-smelling stools, vomiting, abdominal pain along with stool examination showing trophozoites that are tennis-racket shaped is strongly suggestive of giardiasis. The causative organism of this condition is Giardia lamblia.

Infection is common in children and occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. A single cyst can hatch out into two trophozoites, which eventually colonize the duodenum and upper part of the jejunum. It is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the small intestine in humans.

Images of the cyst and trophozoite of giardia are given below:

Giardiasis is diagnosed by identification of cysts or trophozoites in the feces or small intestines, or by nucleic acid amplification tests. Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite that is shaped like a tennis racket. It is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Other options :

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery. Microscopic examination of a saline wet mount of the stool shows the presence of diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile crystals called Charcot-Leyden crystals and nuclear masses called pyknotic bodies. Cysts are spherical with a single nucleus. Trophozoites have an irregular shape with the presence of pseudopodia. An image of the cyst is shown below:


Option C: Cryptosporidium parvum may be asymptomatic or cause a self-limiting febrile illness, with watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss in immunocompetent individuals. Diagnosis is by demonstration of the oocysts in feces. The oocyst is spherical or oval and is acid-fast, appearing red on a blue background. It is shown below:


Option D: Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan and it is present in the large intestine as a commensal. Living trophozoites are large with a macronucleus and have rapid revolving motility. The cysts are large and round with a macronucleus, as shown below.

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency room with a high-grade fever. On examination, bilaterally enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes are present. The findings of peripheral smear examination are shown in the image given below.  Which of the following is a causative organism in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with two nuclei at the tail tip are suggestive of infection with Brugia malayi.

The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi:

  • Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti.
  • Shows kinks and secondary curves.
  • Cephalic space is longer.
  • Carries double stylets at the anterior end.
  • Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films.
  • Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The image given below shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Filariasis: In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis, referred to as Bancroftian filariasis which is transmitted by C. quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). Brugia malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the mansonia mosquito.

It occurs due to the transmission of filariform larva (stage III larva), whereas, microfilaria is the larval stage that circulates in the human blood, which is ingested by mosquitoes during the blood meal. The extrinsic incubation period (duration of the mosquito cycle) is 10-14 days and the reservoirs of infection are humans (predominantly in India) and animals.

Classical filariasis is due to the obstruction of lymphatics by the adult worms, which results in lymph stasis. This leads to the leakage of lymph into the tissues, causing hard-pitting (brawny) oedema. It can present as acute adenolymphangitis, hydrocele, or elephantiasis (shown below).

Occult filariasis (Meyers-Kouwenaar syndrome) results from a hypersensitivity reaction to the microfilarial antigens. Here, the microfilariae are not found in the blood. Symptoms include hepatosplenomegaly, nocturnal cough, or arthritis. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a sign of occult filariasis, characterized by low-grade fever, weight loss, dry nocturnal cough, significant eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels.

Management: Diethyl carbamazepine (DEC) is the drug of choice, given orally at a dose of 6 mg/kg body weight for a period of 12 days. In endemic areas, treatment must be repeated every 2 years. A severe allergic reaction may occur due to the death of microfilaria after the treatment which is controlled with corticosteroids and antihistamines. DEC kills both microfilaria and macrofilaria.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

Related Pearl: Indications of Ivermectin

  • Onchocerciasis
  • Chemoprophylaxis of filariasis
  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Gnathostomiasis
  • Scabies
  • Head lice

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of fever and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, multiple small vesicles are present on the posterior pharyngeal wall as shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing multiple ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, and uvula is characteristic of herpangina. The most likely causative organism in this condition is coxsackie viruses, group A.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackie A infection (a large subgroup of the enteroviruses) in children, but it can also be caused by Coxsackievirus B virus, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71. The initial symptom is an abrupt onset of fever, which could persist for up to five days. Immediately after beginning, a sore throat and dysphagia appear, and nausea and vomiting may also accompany these symptoms. The lesions are small vesicles on the fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall that break down to form ulcers. Treatment is usually supportive only, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include-

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include-

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by the sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

Other options:

Option B: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) causes roseola infantum (exanthem subitum) in infants and young children. The first symptom of the disease is an abrupt onset of fever, which can occasionally range between 39.5 and 40°C and lasts for 3-5 days. A discrete eruption of rose-pink maculopapular appears on the neck and trunk when the temperature drops (shown in the image below); it may later spread to the arms, face, and legs.


Option C: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by poxvirus in children. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin as shown below.


Option D: Streptococcus is responsible for infections of the skin or subcutaneous tissue. It can cause impetigo, ecthyma, erysipelas, and cellulitis. Strep throat is associated with tonsillar and pharyngeal inflammation with exudates rather than vesicles.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding Mitsuda reaction of the lepromin test.

choices.text: It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate
It is a measure of humoral immunity against lepra antigens
Histologically, there is an  infiltration of neutrophils

questions.solution:
The true statement among the following is It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate.

The lepromin test consists of two reactions:

  1. Early reaction (of Fernandez): Develops within 24-48 hrs and lasts for 3-5 days. It is analogous to the tuberculin reaction & not of much significance.
  2. Late reaction (of Mitsuda): It starts in 1 week & peaks at 4 weeks. It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate. It is a measure of cell mediated immunity against lepra antigens. Histologically, there is an infiltration of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & giant cells. It is the more meaningful reaction to determine whether a person can mount an immune reaction against lepra bacilli or not.

The antigens used in lepromin test are

  • Lepromin A (from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli)
  • Dharmendra antigen

questions.text:
An HIV patient presents with fever, cough, chest discomfort, and shortness of breath for 1 week. On chest CT, a halo sign is seen. On LPCB preparation, septate hyphae and conidiophores are seen. On the culture of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, black colonies with galactomannan assay positive are obtained. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this condition?

(LPCB- Lactophenol cotton blue)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Voriconazole is the preferred drug in this condition. 

Invasive aspergillosis occurs due to infection with Aspergillus species. Most cases of invasive aspergillosis involve the lungs. The clinical features include fever, cough which may be productive, chest discomfort, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath.

It is often seen in immunocompromised or debilitated due to prolonged treatment with antibiotics, steroids, and cytotoxics.

Other manifestations of aspergillus species are allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and superficial infections of the eye, external ear, and nasal sinuses.

Diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis is made when the following findings are observed:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

The image below shows septate hyphae with 45o branching and conidiophores:

The image below shows the halo sign on the CT scan:

Other options:

Option A: Itraconazole can be used for the treatment of chronic aspergillosis if there is resistance or failure of voriconazole.

Option C: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for mucormycosis and is the gold standard for induction treatment for cryptococcal meningitis when used in combination with 5-flucytosine. It can be used as a secondary treatment for invasive aspergillosis.

Option D: 5- fluorocytosine is useful in invasive candidiasis, and cryptococcal meningitis if combined with Amp B.

questions.text: A 50-year-old renal transplant patient presented with difficulty in vision. The fundoscopy was done and is shown below. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing the disease?

choices.text: It  can cause pneumonia in bone marrow transplant patients
Congenital infection can cause intrauterine growth retardation
Valganciclovir is the treatment of choice for the infection of eye
Serological assays are important for immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an immunocompromised patient (post-renal transplant) presenting with difficulty in vision and the fundoscopic image showing patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages is suggestive of Cytomegalovirus retinitis. Serological assays are not informative in immunocompromised patients as they are unable to mount a strong enough immunological reaction to be detected by the serological tests.

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management in the case of AIDS patients, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant (Option C).

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in immunocompromised patients like bone marrow transplant recipients can lead to conditions like pneumonia, colitis, retinitis, or disseminated infection (Option A). Congenital infection can lead to features of intrauterine growth retardation, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, microcephaly, and retinitis in the baby (Option B).

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. The PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.

questions.text: A young girl after a school camp develops fever with rashes involving her palms and soles, without eschar. On probing further, she remembers suffering a tick bite during the camp. A blood test reveals antibodies that react with Proteus antigens. Which of the following is the causative organism of the condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and rash involving the palms and soles after a tick bite, with a positive Weil-Felix reaction is suggestive of rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF). RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

RMSF occurs secondary to the bite of a dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles.  The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. 

The following 3 diseases typically present with rash on palms and soles:

  1. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  2. Secondary syphilis
  3. Hand, foot and mouth disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox. Clinical features are fever, headache, lymphadenopathy, and eschar. Weil-Felix reaction is negative. 

Option C: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. It is a sexually transmitted disease. Clinical features are hard chancre, condyloma latum, scaly papular eruptions, and constitutional symptoms.

Option D: Coxiella burnetti causes Q fever. Symptoms are fever, headache, photophobia, etc. Weil-Felix reaction is negative.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Swarming by Proteus species can be inhibited by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Swarming by Proteus species is not inhibited by blood agar.

Proteus species are Gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile rods. They are widespread in the environment and are normal inhabitants of the GIT. P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris most commonly produce infections. The spot-indole test is useful for distinguishing between the two: P. vulgaris is indole positive, whereas P. mirabilis is negative.

Proteus species are urease-positive, non-lactose fermenters. They possess the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA reaction).

Proteus species exhibit swarming on solid media such as blood agar by using their peritrichous flagella. Swarming can be inhibited by:

  • Increasing the concentration of agar to 6%
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Sodium azide
  • Alcohol (5-6%)
  • Sulphonamide
  • Surface-active agents or boric acid
  • MacConkey medium due to the presence of bile
  • CLED (cystine-lactose-electrolyte- deficient) medium.

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

The image below shows swarming of proteus on blood agar.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
